results.title: New decimal coin designs
results.brief_description: Designs for Australia’s six new decimal coins prepared by local designer Stuart Devlin, are presented by the Federal Treasurer, Mr. Harold Holt, and a member of the advisory panel on design Mr. Hal Missingham, who worked closely with the designer and helped solve technical problems. The coins feature seven of Australia’s unique fauna- the spiny anteater, lyre-bird, frilled lizard, feather-tailed glider, platypus, kangaroo and emu.

results.title: Music camp
results.creator_credit: R. Maslyn Williams and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Music students are able to attend a summer camp at Point Lonsdale, Victoria, for three weeks every year. This camp is organised by the National Fitness Council, the Founder being John Bishop. Students attend tutorial classes each morning in the open air and the afternoons are free to swim, fish, sunbathe and practice. In the evenings students usually give a concert for friends and visitors to the camp.

results.title: Moving off on hills, reversing and parking
results.creator_credit: John Edwards, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “How to Drive”.
Having gained experience in the fundamentals of car control, the learner is now ready to acquire the skills required to complete those driving manoeuvres in which co-ordination of control movements plays an important part: the hill start, reversing and parking.

results.title: The Mount Hagen Show
results.creator_credit: Boris Cook and Information and Extension Services for the people of Papua New Guinea
results.brief_description: A mass gathering of highland tribes of diverse customs was indicative of the beginnings of unity and prosperity in Papua and New Guinea. This was the hope expressed by Lord de L’Isle when he declared the Mount Hagen Show open. But it is only the beginning. The response of brightly painted feather bedecked natives to the throb of drums; the incongruousness of their participation in bicycle racing and dodgem cars; the mixed expressions of curiosity and distrust amongst the native spectators, clearly show that the path to change is a long one.

results.title: The Lord Mayor
results.creator_credit: Chris McGill, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Who is at the centre of the administration of a big city? With this film the viewer spends a day in the company of the Lord Mayor of Sydney, Alderman Sir Nicholas Shehadie, OBE. Narrated by John Laws.

results.title: Lifeline to Adelaide
results.creator_credit: John Kingsford-Smith and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Adelaide’s water supply is boosted by the 50 miles of piping from Mannum on the Murray. With the lowest rainfall of any Australian capital, heavy industry expanding each year, and a rapid increase in homes and population, the six reservoirs in the Lofty Ranges are unable to supply enough water for Adelaide’s needs. An extra supply of water is pumped through 72 inch concrete pipes to dams near the city.

results.title: Launceston
results.creator_credit: John Edwards, Peter Young, W. H. Shepherd, Eric Thompson and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life in Australia”.
Aspects of life in Launceston. Industries include Paton and Baldwins woollen mills, Repco ball bearing factory, timber mills and furniture manufacturers. Shows schools, the general hospital, churches, and the historic home of Entally built in 1820. Motor racing at Longford, bicycyle racing, water skiing and archery are popular forms of recreation. Theatres, restaurants and night clubs, provide a variety of evening entertainment.
